did.abstract: These diaries include daily entries relating to family and business, travels, sittings, museum work, etc. The diary of 1824 June 9-July 4 covers the period of Peale's last courtship. Three of the diaries are duplicated from originals elsewhere: No. 3 in the Henry E. Huntington Library, and Nos. 7 and 9 in Fordham University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This collection is also available on microfilm (Film 240). The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

odd.head: Early American History Not
odd.p: Charles Willson Peale’s diaries offer a remarkable window into the world of early America. Peale kept diaries from 1760 until his death. There are twenty-six discreet volumes. Peale’s entries are often very detailed and content rich. Peale’s life spanned a remarkable number of events. He was very active in the American Revolution, which is chronicled here, and his continued work as an artist and innovator in early America is well-recorded here, as are the smaller anecdotes of life, like social outings and family affairs. There are also many sketches scattered throughout the volumes. The diaries not only provide insight into Peale’s own life but often record events happening within Philadelphia and beyond.
